arguments.argument: Explicit consent gives individuals control over their personal data and how it's used.
It protects privacy by ensuring people are aware of and agree to the data collection.
Explicit consent reduces the risk of companies abusing or misusing personal data.
It aligns with ethical principles, respecting individual autonomy and privacy rights.
Companies would be more transparent about their data practices, fostering trust with customers.
Explicit consent helps to ensure data security by clarifying the scope and limits of data collection.
It would reduce the risk of data breaches by allowing users to opt out of unnecessary data collection.
By requiring consent, individuals are informed about the potential risks associated with data collection.
This would help prevent companies from gathering excessive or irrelevant data from users.
Explicit consent promotes accountability, as companies would have to prove they obtained permission to collect data.
Requiring explicit consent may slow down the data collection process and hinder business efficiency.
Many users may ignore or misunderstand consent forms, leading to ineffective or incomplete consent.
It could create unnecessary barriers for companies and lead to increased operational costs.
Users may feel overwhelmed by frequent requests for consent, leading to consent fatigue and disengagement.
Explicit consent may not be effective in preventing misuse if users are not fully informed about the implications.
Companies already provide privacy policies and opt-out options, which should be sufficient for data protection.
Requiring explicit consent may be challenging to implement across different countries with varying laws and regulations.
It may not address the root causes of data misuse, such as inadequate security measures or poorly managed databases.
Explicit consent might not be practical for certain industries that rely on data collection for user experience or personalization.
Mandatory consent could create a false sense of security, leading users to believe their data is always safe when it may not be.
